feed.title: Simon Cowell Has Learned to Keep His Big Mouth Shut
feed.subtitle: The X Factor judge on Whitney Houston, Britney Spears and learning to eat humble pie.

category.term: 291~Simon Cowell~The X Factor (TV Show)~Nicole Scherzinger~L.A Reid
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Of all the things Simon Cowell expected to take away from his first season of The X Factor, humility was not one of them. And yet, one year and two fired judges later, the man whose reputation is defined by his reckless bravado is eating humble pie, admitting rather meekly that his audacity at predicting an average of 20 million viewers per week set up his show for disappointment.

"I shot my big mouth off, as usual," Cowell said of his early ratings predictions, which ultimately proved to be approximately seven million more viewers than the first season regularly attracted. "I've learned a big lesson: keep your mouth shut"

Cowell's about-face isn't the only change expected in the show's second season.

Speaking during a recent conference call, Cowell and fellow X Factor host L.A Reid – the only holdover from the first season after Paula Abdul and former Pussycat Doll Nicole Scherzinger were let go – admitted that, while a great start, the British import's inaugural season served as a valuable learning experience. And now, big changes for the reality competition are on the horizon.

Changes like the return of co-ed hosts, which was abandoned in the first season after Scherzinger, initially hired to host, replaced Cheryl Cole as a judge.

"I always wanted a boy and a girl to host the show," Cowell explained. "I think that's definitely going to happen now."

The balanced gender theme will also be evident at the judges table, which will once again feature two American ladies alongside Cowell and Reid.

But despite frequent requests for confirmation of the rumours that Britney Spears and Janet Jackson, to name but two of the big names bandied about the internet, will be filling Scherzinger and Abdul's former posts, both judges remained mum.

"It's true to say that a lot more people have entered the frame this year and we really waited to see who was going to contact us before we actually contacted people," Cowell said. "We will meet a number of people over the next few weeks, mainly to explain to them that this is a big commitment when you do a show like this because of the mentoring aspect. But I can't confirm or deny any of these rumors at the moment."

Despite Cowell's coyness, Reid was willing to address one particular rumoured host: the late Whitney Houston.

"We love Whitney and we would have certainly considered it, but the truth is it never quite came to that," he said of the recently deceased singer, with whom he frequently collaborated. "There was an interest there, but we never actually had meetings about it…We didn't really get that far. So I don't think it's proper to comment beyond that."

Both men agreed there is a good chance of a Houston tribute episode in the future, assuming their rival shows don't do it as well.

"If we decide to do it, I think we have to do it in a different way," Cowell said. "But the important thing is that we're going to continually pay tribute to Whitney Houston on this show, because we love her, we love her songs, and there probably won't ever be a season where you won't hear a Whitney song. They're timeless."

Both the ratings decline of Cowell's former gig, American Idol, and the surprise surge of its NBC counterpart, The Voice, are clearly weighing heavily on Cowell's mind. So much so that recently, the producer issued a challenge, via Twitter, to have all three show's winners battle in a musical "super final." It was an idea that Voice judge Adam Levine and Idol producer Nigel Lythgoe quickly dismissed.

"I was very disappointed with the reactions from the other two shows because I like the idea of super finals," Cowell lamented. "I thought it would be something different. They've both bottled it for now, but I spoke to L.A. and we're still up for it."

Of course, it's that drive to succeed that drove Cowell to make his ill-fated ratings prediction in the first place and, as he nears the March 14 start of open call X Factor auditions, the big-mouthed television personality will have plenty of chances to test out his new dedication to realistic expectations.

"I always go into this with a sense of excitement…so I absolutely expect the second season to do better than the first season," he said. "I'm not doing this because you want to be third or fourth; you throw everything you can to give yourself a shot at winning.

"I learned a lot from last year, genuinely learned a lot. And I think we've learned how we can make the show better and I like the fact that it's got very competitive now. It's kind of exciting."

jond@dose.ca
